description: From Middle English godeman, equivalent to good +â€Ž man.

entries.meaning: (now rare, chiefly Scotland) A familiar appellation of civility for a man. [from 10th c.]
(now Scotland or historical) A husband; the master of a house or family. [from 13th c.]
examples: Come, let us take our fill of love until the morning: let us solace ourselves with loves.  For the goodman is not at home, he is gone a long journey.
